div.head:
FORSTER AND HUMBOLDT—ANOTHER LET-
TER FROM THE AUTHOR OF COSMOS.
div.p:
“How shall I, honored sir, thank you warmly
enough for having followed the friendly advice
given you by the noble and liberal Grand Duke in
Wilhelmsthal! You have furnished an admirable,
vigorously written, physiognomically accurate and
impartial biography of my departed friend. You
have employed me for two long nights, for I have
read page for page of your excellent work. It has
caused me to experience many happy and many sad
emotions. For thirty years I have had leisure only
at night. I have spent half a century—no matter
whither a restless, wandering life has led me—in
telling myself and others how much I owed to my
teacher and friend, George Forster, in generalizing
my views of nature, and in strengthening and de-
veloping that which had begun to dawn within me
before that happy intimacy took place.

“In these nights, disposed to sadness, as my
strength is now rapidly failing, I have been vividly
reminded of the singular similarities and contrasts
exhibited in all the relations of George Forster’s
and my own life. A like direction of political
opinions—mine not derived from Forster, but ante-
dating his—the first view of the ocean by the side
of the circumnavigator, at a time when I little
hoped that twelve years later I, too, would be on
the waters of the South Seas; my sojourn in Lon-
don at the time when [Captain] Cook’s widow was
yet living, and when Sir Joseph Banks took a liking
to me; in my Siberian expedition I came upon the
banks of the Samara, whence the eldest Forster
sent to Linnæus, at Upsala, a specimen of the wild
waijer(?); Reinhold Forster, accompanied by the
lad George, having visited the spot in 1765, four
years before I was born, which I reached in 1825;
under the Czar Alexander I was invited by Count
Rumanzoff, in 1812, to a great scientiffcscientific expedition
through the interior of Asia, as George Forster,
under the Empress Catharine, had been invited to
join the scientific voyage round the world by Com-
modore Mulowsky;—a like bitter disappointment;
both expeditions were frustrated by wars with the
French and Turks.

“How your valued gift has stirred up within me
old memories! Your whole Sixth Book is mas-
terly—but fills me with sadness; this is espe-
cially the case with the 8th, 9th and 10th lines
from the bottom of page 251—and yet they were
welcome!

closer.salute:
“With the renewed expression of my heartfelt
thanks and friendly esteem, I remain,
“Your obedient A. V. Humboldt.

div.p:
“I am personally very thankful to you for having
so warmly and amiably mentioned my unyielding
and faithful attachment to and admiration for
George Forster, at a time when you could not have
known that your work would fall into my hands.—
I do not fear that you will, from the fourth volume
of my ‘Kosmos,’ judge me to be a mere believer
in the ‘change of matter,’ like Moleschott, (page
18 of your preface,) for one can believe in the
ever-varying fettering and unfettering of matter,
without, on that account, doubting the existence
of the higher, spiritual essence in the animal or-
ganization.”

The George Forster, of whose biography Hum-
boldt speaks with so much warmth, was born at
Nassenhuten, near Dantsic, in 1754. His father was
John Reinhold Forster, Prussian Privy Councillor
and Professor of Natural History (Zoology) at the
University of Halle. He was a descendant of the
Lords Forester of Scotland, who had taken refuge
in Polish Prussia. In 1772 George accompanied
his father on Captain Cook’s second exploring ex-
pedition—the father having been appointed Natu-
ralist to the expedition, and both father and son
being masters of the English language. George
subsequently became the historian of the expedi-
tion. In 1792 George Forster, then first librarian
of the Elector of Mayence, embraced with fervor
the cause of the French revolutionists, and was sent
as deputy from Mayence to the Convention at Paris.
He was in Paris when the city of Mayence was re-
captured by Prussia, which involved the confisca-
tion of all his property, including his books and
manuscripts.

Forster, now a ruined man, separated from his
wife, and determined to leave Europe and proceed
to the Indies. With this end in view he com-
menced the study of the Oriental languages. His
exertions and his sufferings, however, were too
great, and he died in Paris in 1794. His labors in
both the literary and scientific departments of
knowledge were immense, inferior only to those of
his father, who, whether as a zoologist, botanist,
historian or linguist—he spoke and wrote seven-
teen modern and dead languages—had few superi-
ors in the seventeenth century.

An enterprising American publisher, we doubt
not, would find his account in a translation of
“George Forster’s Life at Home and Abroad.”—N.
Y. Evening Post.
